Hi everybody,

I recently stumbled upon a paper that I found very inspiring=
 and somehow changed my perspective on neural networks. 

Polychronization:=
 Computation with spikes
http://www.izhikevich.org/publications/spnet.htm
(=
for a rough but fast impression of the idea I recommend fig. 2 and fig. 6)
=

Besides the particular concept of polychronous groups analyzed in this stu=
dy, the paper highlights the fact that neurons in natural neural networks h=
ave connections with heterogenous conduction delays (with submillisecond pr=
ecision) and that this heterogeneity contributes to the function of the net=
work. 

As with increasing distance of two neurons the conduction delay bet=
ween both neurons increases as well which in turn affects the function of t=
he neurons, I am wondering whether heterogenous conduction delays represent=
 an important additional link to relate the form of a network to its functi=
on. I know, this is true for something like sound localization (http://en.w=
ikipedia.org/wiki/Coincidence_detection_in_neurobiology#Sound_localization)=
 but maybe heterogenous conduction delays are also important in the impleme=
ntation of other functions.

Of course, I immediately thought about impleme=
nting it in HyperNEAT but haven't done it yet ;)

Just in case someone of y=
ou finds time to read this paper I would be interested in hearing your thou=
ghts about the ideas in it and whether you think they can be combined with =
methods in the field of Artificial Development.

Best,
Martin
